description: The round payoff this round was 5. You, Kate chose to play option 1.John chose to play option 1. You received a payoff of 0.
Mutual defection (both choosing option 2) results in catastrophic losses (round input × 1000), creating overwhelming incentives for players to avoid this outcome
Cooperation (both choosing option 1) is stable in repeated rounds due to the threat of severe retaliation, outweighing short-term gains from defection
The payoff asymmetry (small gain/loss from unilateral defection vs. massive loss from mutual defection) prioritizes risk aversion over exploitation
Rational players will default to option 1 to ensure a safe payoff (0) and avoid triggering mutual punishment cycles
The game’s structure resembles an extreme prisoner’s dilemma, where cooperation dominates due to disproportionate penalties for mutual defection
